Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They offer small gestures of kindness in daily interactions
Story: I sat in the principal’s office, my son fidgeting beside me, the words “bullying incident” echoing in my mind. As a father, I knew I was expected to be present, to show up for my child, to guide him and, when necessary, correct him. The school expected me to respond firmly, to ensure this wouldn’t happen again. But as a Christian, I was taught to show love and kindness, to forgive, to see the good in others—even when they made mistakes. I wanted to comfort my son, to remind him that everyone deserves compassion, even when they’ve done wrong. Yet, I also felt the weight of responsibility to teach him that his actions have consequences, that hurting others is never acceptable. My heart twisted as I tried to reconcile these roles—how could I be both the firm father and the loving Christian in this moment? The principal’s expectant gaze pressed on me, and I felt the tension rise, unsure which path to take.
